name: Zscaler Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
title: Zscaler Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
body:
In this article, you'll learn how to integrate Zscaler Web Proxy with SecurityCoach. Once you set up this integration, data provided by Zscaler will be available under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Important:To configure the Zscaler integration, you'll need access to a Zscaler admin account.

Tip:SecurityCoach also supports integrating Zscaler as a Splunk vendor. If your organization uses Splunk for security information and event management, we recommend integrating through Splunk instead by following our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.

Copy Your Organization Key and API Key

Before you can set up this integration in your Zscaler console, you must authorize the configuration and copy your organization key from the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. If you are using a Cloud Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Zscaler server for the integration, you will also need to copy your API key.

To locate and copy your organization key and API key, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate the Zscaler card and click Configure.
  3. From the Select Zscaler Server drop-down menu, select your server.
  4. Click Authorize.

  5. In the modal that opens, click OK.
  6. Copy and save your Organization Key. If you selected Zscaler Cloud NSS in step 3 above, also copy and save your API Gateway Key.
    Note: These keys are needed to complete the process outlined in the Set Up the Integration in Your Zscaler Console section of this article.

Set Up the Integration in Your Zscaler Console

Once you have copied the needed keys from SecurityCoach, you can set up the Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) or Cloud NSS integration in your Zscaler console. Click the links below to learn how to set up your specific integration.

Set Up the Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Integration in Your Zscaler Console

Set Up the Cloud Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Integration in Your Zscaler Console

Note:NSS does not support Transport Layer Security (TLS). This means that the NSS integration will send events in plain text. However, Cloud NSS does offer an HTTPS endpoint that supports TLS.

Set Up the Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Integration in Your Zscaler Console

Once you have copied your organization key, you can set up the NSS integration in your Zscaler console by following the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Zscaler Admin Portal and navigate to Administration > Nanolog Streaming Service.
  2. Click the pencil icon to update the NSS feed.

  3. On the Edit NSS Feed page, edit the fields listed below.
    1. SIEM Destination Type: Select FQDN.

    2. SIEM FQDN: Enter the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) for your KnowBe4 instance into the field. To find the FQDN for your KnowBe4 instance, see the table below:

      KnowBe4 Instance FQDN
      United States syslog.training.knowbe4.com
      European Union syslog.eu.knowbe4.com
      Canada syslog.ca.knowbe4.com
      United Kingdom syslog.uk.knowbe4.com
      Germany syslog.de.knowbe4.com
    3. SIEM TCP Port: Update the value in the field to "5000".
    4. Feed Output Type: Select Custom.
    5. Feed Output Format: Copy and paste the code block below into this field. Then, replace [x] with your organization key:
      Note:When pasting the code block, ensure the text is one single line. Besides adding your organization key, do not make any other changes to the code block.
      zscaler-nss CEF:0|Zscaler|NSS|4.1|NULL|NULL|NULL|org_key=[x]\tvendor_code_name=zscaler\tlog_type=web\tcat=%s{action}\tdevTime=%s{mon} %02d{dd} %d{yy} %02d{hh}:%02d{mm}:%02d{ss} %s{tz}\tdevTimeFormat=MMM dd yyyy HH:mm:ssz\tsourceAddress=%s{cip}\tdst=%s{sip}\trealm=%s{location}\tusrName=%s{login}\tsrcBytes=%d{reqsize}\tpolicy=%s{reason}\trecordid=%d{recordid}\thostname=%s{ehost}\tappproto=%s{proto}\turlcategory=%s{urlcat}\tappclass=%s{appclass}\tappname=%s{appname}\tmalwareclass=%s{malwareclass}\tthreatname=%s{threatname}\tdlpdict=%s{dlpdict}\tdlpeng=%s{dlpeng}\tfiletype=%s{filetype}\turl=%s{eurl}\tdevicehostname=%s{devicehostname}\n
    6. User Obfuscation: Select Disabled.
    7. Timezone: Select GMT from the drop-down menu.
    8. Duplicate Logs: Select Disabled from the drop-down menu.
    9. Policy Action: Select Blocked from the drop-down menu.
    10. Policy Reason: Select Any from the drop-down menu.

  4. Click Save.
  5. Follow the steps below to find the public IP address for your NSS VM:
    1. Log in to your NSS VM.
    2. Run the following command: 
      [zsroot@NSS ~]$ curl ipinfo.io/ip
    3. Copy the IP address that is found.
  6. Submit a support ticket that includes your NSS VM IP Address. A member of our support team will whitelist your IP address and ensure that Zscaler has been successfully integrated.
    Important:If your NSS VM IP address ever changes, reach out to support again so they can whitelist your new IP address.

Once you’ve successfully set up this integration, you can manage your detection rules for Zscaler on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach.

Set Up the Cloud Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Integration in Your Zscaler Console

Once you have copied your organization key and API key, you can set up the Cloud NSS integration in your Zscaler console. To set up the Cloud NSS integration in your Zscaler console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Zscaler Admin Portal and navigate to Administration > Nanolog Streaming Service.
  2. Click the pencil icon to update the Cloud NSS feed.
  3. On the Edit Cloud NSS Feed page, edit the fields listed below.
    1. SIEM Type: Select Other.

    2. API URL: Enter the URL for your KnowBe4 instance into the field. To find the URL for your KnowBe4 instance, see the table below:

      KnowBe4 Instance URL
      United States https://syslog-webhook.training.knowbe4.com/v1/syslog
      European Union https://syslog-webhook.eu.knowbe4.com/v1/syslog
      Canada https://syslog-webhook.ca.knowbe4.com/v1/syslog
      United Kingdom https://syslog-webhook.uk.knowbe4.com/v1/syslog
      Germany https://syslog-webhook.de.knowbe4.com/v1/syslog
    3. Key1: Enter "x-api-key" into the field.
    4. Value1: Enter your API key into the field.
    5. Feed Output Type: Select JSON.
    6. Feed Output Format: Copy and paste the code block below into this field. Then, replace [x] with your organization key:
      Note:When pasting the code block, ensure the text is one single line. Besides adding your organization key, do not make any other changes to the code block.
      \{"sourcetype": "zscalernss-web","org_key":"[x]","vendor_code_name":"zscaler","log_type":"web","cat":"%s{action}","devTime":"%s{mon} %02d{dd} %d{yy} %02d{hh}:%02d{mm}:%02d{ss} %s{tz}","devTimeFormat":"MMM dd yyyy HH:mm:ssz","policy":"%s{reason}","recordid":"%d{recordid}","malwareclass":"%s{malwareclass}","urlcategory":"%s{urlcat}","realm":"%s{location}","sourceAddress":"%s{cip}","srcBytes":"%d{reqsize}","usrName":"%s{login}","url":"%s{eurl}","hostname":"%s{ehost}","appproto":"%s{proto}","threatname":"%s{threatname}","filetype":"%s{filetype}","appclass":"%s{appclass}","appname":"%s{appname}","dlpeng":"%s{dlpeng}","dlpdict":"%s{dlpdict}","devicehostname":"%s{devicehostname}"\}
    7. Timezone: Select GMT from the drop-down menu.
    8. Policy Action: Select Blocked from the drop-down menu.
    9. Policy Reason: Select Any from the drop-down menu.

  4. Click Save.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Zscaler, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully set up this integration, you can manage detection rules for Zscaler on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

Delete the Integration in Your Zscaler Console

If you want to delete your Zscaler integration with SecurityCoach, you can delete it in your Zscaler console. For more information, on how to delete your Zscaler integration, see the sections below.

Delete the Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Integration in Your Zscaler Console

To delete the NSS integration in your Zscaler console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Zscaler Admin Portal and navigate to Administration > Nanolog Streaming Service.
  2. Select NSS Feeds.

  3. Locate the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) you want to remove. To find the FQDN for your KnowBe4 instance, see the table below:

    KnowBe4 Instance FQDN
    United States syslog.training.knowbe4.com
    European Union syslog.eu.knowbe4.com
    Canada syslog.ca.knowbe4.com
    United Kingdom syslog.uk.knowbe4.com
    Germany syslog.de.knowbe4.com
  4. Select the pencil icon.

  5. Click Delete, then click Confirm.

Delete the Cloud Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) Integration in Your Zscaler Console

To delete the Cloud NSS integration in your Zscaler console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Zscaler Admin Portal and navigate to Administration > Nanolog Streaming Service.
  2. Select Cloud NSS Feeds.

  3. Locate the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) you want to remove. To find the FQDN for your KnowBe4 instance, see the table below:

    KnowBe4 Instance FQDN
    United States syslog.training.knowbe4.com
    European Union syslog.eu.knowbe4.com
    Canada syslog.ca.knowbe4.com
    United Kingdom syslog.uk.knowbe4.com
    Germany syslog.de.knowbe4.com
  4. Select the pencil icon.

  5. Click Delete, then click Confirm.

images.alt:
The provided image displays the **Zscaler** integration setup screen.

**Key UI Elements and Text:**

1.  **Header:** The page title is **Zscaler**. A navigation link, **← Back to Integrations**, is present in the top right corner.
2.  **Instructional Banner:** A light blue banner contains guidance text: "For more information about configuring this vendor integration, click **Configuration Help.**" A white button labeled **Configuration Help** is positioned within this banner.
3.  **Server Selection Field:** A section labeled **Select Zscaler Server:** features a mandatory dropdown input field displaying the placeholder text **Select option**.
4.  **Authorization Section:** A separate panel provides the instruction: "Click on the authorize button to enable Zscaler integration." This instruction is accompanied by a prominent blue action button labeled **Authorize**.

**Context:** The screen facilitates the initial setup and authorization steps required to integrate the Zscaler service with the hosting platform, specifically requiring the user to select a server instance and grant authorization.
images.context:
menu, select your server.
Click Authorize.

images.alt:
The image displays the active configuration page for a **Zscaler** integration, indicated by the 'Active' status badge.

**UI Elements and Text:**

*   **Navigation:** A link labeled **Back to Integrations** is present in the upper right.
*   **Alert Banner (Green):** A notification banner reads: "Ready to view and enable detection rules for Zscaler?" It contains a primary call-to-action button: **Configure Detection Rules** (green).
*   **Main Panel Title:** **Zscaler Integration - Zscaler NSS**.
*   **Destructive Action:** A prominent red button labeled **Delete Registration** is visible.
*   **Input Field:** A field labeled **Organization Key** displays a blurred, sensitive value (the field and label are highlighted by an orange instructional border).

images.alt:
This image is a view of an active configuration page for the **Zscaler** integration within a security or management platform.

**Header and Status:**
*   The page title is **Zscaler** with a status label **Active** displayed in a blue capsule.
*   A navigational link, **← Back to Integrations**, is present in the top right corner.

**Action Prompt Panel:**
*   A light green banner contains a prompt: **Ready to view and enable detection rules for Zscaler?**
*   An accompanying primary action button is labeled **Configure Detection Rules** (green).

**Integration Details Panel:**
*   The main configuration panel is titled **Zscaler Integration - Zscaler Cloud NSS**.
*   A destructive action button is prominently placed on the right: **Delete Registration** (red).
*   The panel displays two authentication fields (highlighted by orange borders, indicating required or configured values):
    1. **Organization Key:** Contains a blurred/redacted key value in a text input box.
    2. **API Gateway Key:** Contains a blurred/redacted key value in a text input box.

images.context: Click the pencil icon to update the NSS feed.
eason: Select Any from the drop-down menu.

images.alt:
This screen capture displays the configuration interface for an "Edit Cloud NSS Feed." The UI is divided into four primary sections: General, SIEM Connectivity, Formatting, and Web Log Filters.

**1. GENERAL**
*   **Feed Name:** Set to "Zscaler Webhook."
*   **NSS Type:** Configured for **NSS for Web** (segmented control selected).
*   **Status:** Set to **Enabled** (segmented control selected).
*   **SIEM Rate:** Set to **Unlimited** (segmented control selected).

**2. SIEM CONNECTIVITY**
*   **SIEM Type (a):** Dropdown set to **Other**.
*   **OAuth 2.0 Authentication:** Disabled (toggle switch set to Off/Red X).
*   **Max Batch Size:** Value set to **16** KB.
*   **API URL (b):** The endpoint is displayed as `https://syslog-webhook.training.knowbe4.com/v1/syslog`.
*   **HTTP Headers (c, d):** One header is configured. Key 1 is set to `x-api-key`, and Value 1 is hidden behind masked characters, indicating a sensitive token. An action button, "+ Add HTTP Header," is available.

**3. FORMATTING**
*   **Log Type:** Dropdown set to **Web Log**.
*   **Feed Output Type (e):** Dropdown set to **JSON**.
*   **JSON Array Notation:** Enabled (checkbox selected).
*   **Feed Output Format (f):** A large, read-only text area displays the complex JSON format definition using various field macros (e.g., `%d{datetime}`, `%s{reason}`, `%s{url}`).
*   **Timezone (g):** Dropdown set to **GMT**.

**4. WEB LOG FILTERS**
*   **Filter Tabs:** The **Action** tab is currently selected, with other available filter categories including Who, From Where, Transaction, To Where, Security, File Type, and DLP.
*   **Policy Action (h):** Filter set to **Blocked**.
*   **Policy Reason (i):** Filter set to **Any**.

**Action Bar**
The configuration is concluded with three functional buttons: **Save**, **Cancel**, and **Delete**.
images.context: rong>: Select Any from the drop-down menu.

images.alt:
This is the "Zscaler User Mapping" configuration panel, designed to link Zscaler endpoint events to specific user identifiers.

**Header and Context:**
*   **Title:** Zscaler User Mapping
*   **Description:** Instructions detail mapping users via "configuring your mapping rules or uploading a CSV file." A linked resource, "Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article," is provided for further information.

**Primary Navigation (Tabs):**
*   **Mapping Rules (Recommended):** The active, selected tab.
*   **CSV File Upload:** An inactive tab option.

**Active Panel: Configure Mapping Rules**
*   **Subtitle:** Configure Mapping Rules
*   **Instruction:** Users must configure rules to map Zscaler data to "KMSAT user data fields." This method is labeled as recommended.
*   **Rule Definition UI:** A single, horizontal mapping rule is partially defined:
    *   Source System: Zscaler
    *   Zscaler Data Field: A static field identifier labeled "Hostname."
    *   Operator: "is"
    *   Target System Field: Labeled "Knowbe4 User Data Field," with a dropdown placeholder reading "Select option."
    *   Action Button: "Add Field" (Used for adding criteria to the current rule).
*   **Rule Management Link:** "Add Another Rule" is available below the current configuration line.

**Action Buttons (Footer):**
*   **Save:** Primary blue, solid button for saving configuration changes.
*   **Delete Integration:** Secondary red-bordered button for removing the integration.

This technical image displays a web-based management interface for the **Nanolog Streaming Service**.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The primary system navigation (vertical, left pane) is visible, with the **Administration** section currently selected and highlighted in blue.
*   The overall context suggests management within a Zscaler/ZIA environment.

**Main UI Elements and Text:**
*   **Service Header:** Nanolog Streaming Service.
*   **Sub-Navigation Tabs:** Three tabs are displayed for configuration management:
    1.  NSS Servers
    2.  **NSS Feeds** (Currently active, indicated by an orange underline)
    3.  Cloud NSS Feeds
*   **Action Bar (Toolbar):** Three action links are available regardless of the selected tab:
    *   Add NSS Server (Icon: Plus)
    *   Deploy NSS Virtual Appliance (Icon: Deployment/Upload)
    *   Download MIB Files (Icon: Download)

**Data Grid:**
*   The content area displays a data grid (table) likely listing existing feeds or servers.
*   **Column Headers:** No., Server Name (sortable/filterable), Type (sortable/filterable), and Status (sortable).
*   **Data Row:** One entry is visible (Row 1), with the Server Name and Type redacted. The **Status** field explicitly shows **Enabled**.

This image displays the **Nanolog Streaming Service** configuration page, specifically focusing on the **NSS Feeds** management tab.

**UI Context and Navigation:**

1.  **Page Title:** Nanolog Streaming Service.
2.  **Navigation Tabs:** Three primary tabs are visible: NSS Servers, **NSS Feeds** (currently selected and active), and Cloud NSS Feeds.
3.  **Action Buttons:** Links for creating new feeds are present: "+ Add NSS Feed" and "+ Add MCAS NSS Feed."
4.  **Search Function:** A search bar labeled "Search..." is located in the upper right corner.

**Data Table (NSS Feeds List):**

The table displays one configured feed (Row No. 1) with the following columnar structure and visible details:

| Column Header | Visible Details | Actions/Controls |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Feed Overview** | Feed Name (Censored), NSS Server (Censored), Status (Censored), Output Destination (Censored), Log Type (Censored), Feed Type (Censored), and a "More..." link. | N/A |
| **Log Filter** | Policy Action: Blocked | N/A |
| **Feed Output Format** | Content is blurred/censored. | N/A |
| **Feed Attributes** | Duplicate Logs: Disabled, Timezone: GMT, SIEM Rate: Unlimited | A pencil (Edit) icon is available for modification, along with a three-dot (ellipsis) menu in the column header for column customization. |

An orange arrow specifically highlights the **Edit (pencil) icon** associated with the Feed Attributes column, indicating the user interface mechanism for modifying the configuration details of the listed feed.

This image displays the modal configuration dialog for **"Edit NSS Feed"** within a network security or logging interface. The form is organized into two primary columns containing input fields and controls for defining a Network Stream Service (NSS) data feed, primarily for SIEM integration.

### Header and Context

*   **Title:** Edit NSS Feed.
*   **Action:** A close button (X) is present in the upper right corner.
*   **Section Title:** NSS FEED.

### Configuration Fields

**Left Column Elements:**

*   **Feed Name:** Text input field.
*   **NSS Server:** Dropdown selection menu.
*   **SIEM Destination Type:** Toggle switch, with **FQDN** selected over "IP Address."
*   **SIEM TCP Port:** Text input field for the port number.
*   **SIEM Rate:** Toggle switch, with **Unlimited** selected over "Limited."
*   **Log Type:** Dropdown selection menu.
*   **Feed Escape Character:** Text input field with placeholder "Enter Text."
*   **Feed Output Format:** Large multiline text area.
*   **Timezone:** Configuration label.

**Right Column Elements:**

*   **NSS Type:** Text input field.
*   **Status:** Toggle switch, with **Enabled** selected over "Disabled."
*   **SIEM FQDN:** Text input field (conditional based on SIEM Destination Type selection).
*   **Feed Output Type:** Dropdown selection menu.
*   **Duplicate Logs:** Configuration label.

### Footer Actions

The footer contains three primary action buttons:

1.  **Save:** Primary blue button for committing changes.
2.  **Cancel:** Text button for discarding changes.
3.  **Delete:** Red-bordered button, positioned separately on the far right, indicating a destructive action. (An illustrative arrow points to this button).

This image displays a screenshot of a web-based user interface, specifically within the **Nanolog Streaming Service** configuration page.

**Navigation and Context:**

*   **Header:** The main title is "Nanolog Streaming Service."
*   **Sidebar Navigation (Left):** The **Administration** section (highlighted in blue with gear icons) is currently selected. Other visible items include ZIA, Dashboard, Analytics, Policy, Activation, and Search.
*   **Tab Navigation (Center Top):** Three primary tabs are available: **NSS Servers** (currently active, indicated by the underline), **NSS Feeds**, and **Cloud NSS Feeds** (highlighted with an orange box for reference, but not selected).

**Main Content (NSS Servers Tab):**

*   **Action Bar:** Below the tabs, three action links are visible:
    *   **+ Add NSS Server**
    *   **Deploy NSS Virtual Appliance**
    *   **Download MIB Files**
*   **Data Table:** A table lists configured NSS Servers with four columns:
    *   **No.** (Numbered rows: 1, 2, 3)
    *   **Server Name** (Content blurred/redacted)
    *   **Type** (Content blurred/redacted)
    *   **Status** (Displays operational state for each server):
        *   Row 1: Enabled
        *   Row 2: Enabled
        *   Row 3: Disabled

This image displays the **Nanolog Streaming Service** (NSS) interface for managing streaming feeds, specifically highlighting the **Cloud NSS Feeds** tab, which is currently active.

**UI Context and Navigation:**
The main navigation includes three tabs: "NSS Servers," "NSS Feeds," and "Cloud NSS Feeds." Below the navigation is the primary creation action: **+ Add Cloud NSS Feed**. A search bar labeled "Search..." with an accompanying magnifying glass icon is located in the upper right.

**Data Table Structure:**
The screen presents a data grid with the following column headers:
1. No.
2. Feed Overview
3. Log Filter
4. Feed Output Format
5. Feed Attributes
6. Last Connectivity Test
7. Action Icons (indicated by a three-dot menu in the header)

**Feed Details (Row 1):**
Row 1 lists a single feed.
*   The **Feed Overview** column lists multiple attributes, including **FEED NAME, STATUS, API URL, SIEM TYPE, FEED OUTPUT TYPE,** and **LOG TYPE** (specific values are redacted).
*   The **Feed Attributes** column specifies configuration settings: **TIME ZONE GMT** and **MAX BATCH SIZE 16 KB**.
*   The **Action Icons** column contains a blue cloud icon (likely for connectivity testing or deployment) and a blue **Edit** (pencil) icon, which is emphasized by an orange directional arrow.

This image displays the **"Edit Cloud NSS Feed"** configuration dialog box.

The dialog is organized into two primary sections: **Formatting** and **Web Log Filters**.

**1. Formatting Section:**
This section contains five input fields related to log output configuration:
*   **Log Type:** A dropdown selection field (content is obscured/blurred).
*   **Feed Output Type:** A dropdown selection field (content is obscured/blurred).
*   **Feed Escape Character:** A text input field placeholder states "Enter Text".
*   **Feed Output Format:** A large, multi-line text area (content is highly obscured/blurred).
*   **Timezone:** A dropdown selection, currently set to **"GMT"**.

**2. Web Log Filters Section:**
This section uses a tabbed interface to manage log filtering criteria. The available tabs are:
*   **Action** (Currently selected and underlined)
*   **Who**
*   **From Where**
*   **Transaction**
*   **To Where**
*   **Security**
*   **File Type**
*   **DLP**

The content shown under the active **"Action"** tab is titled **"WEB LOG FILTERS"** and contains two input fields:
*   **Policy Action:** A dropdown selection field (content is obscured/blurred).
*   **Policy Reason:** A dropdown selection field (content is obscured/blurred).

**3. Action Buttons (Footer):**
The footer of the dialog provides three action buttons:
*   **Save:** A primary, dark blue button.
*   **Cancel:** A standard text link.
*   **Delete:** A secondary button with a red border and text, visually highlighted by an orange arrow pointing towards it.
